item.title: International Financial Markets Through 150 Years: Evaluating Stylized Facts
item.description: arXiv:2504.08611v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: In the theory of financial markets, a stylized fact is a qualitative summary of a pattern in financial market data that is observed across multiple assets, asset classes and time horizons. In this article, we test a set of eleven stylized facts for financial market data. Our main contribution is to consider a broad range of geographical regions across Asia, continental Europe, and the US over a time period of 150 years, as well as two of the most traded cryptocurrencies, thus providing insights into the robustness and generalizability of commonly known stylized facts.
item.dc:creator: Sara A. Safari, Maximilian Janisch, Thomas Leh\'ericy
